review.title: Networks of Influence Diagrams: A Formalism for Representing Agents' Beliefs and Decision-Making Processes
review.abstract: This paper presents Networks of Influence Diagrams (NID), a compact, natural and highly expressive language for reasoning about agents beliefs and decision-making processes. NIDs are graphical structures in which agents mental models are represented as nodes in a network; a mental model for an agent may itself use descriptions of the mental models of other agents. NIDs are demonstrated by examples, showing how they can be used to describe conflicting and cyclic belief structures, and certain forms of bounded rationality. In an opponent modeling domain, NIDs were able to outperform other computational agents whose strategies were not known in advance. NIDs are equivalent in representation to Bayesian games but they are more compact and structured than this formalism. In particular, the equilibrium definition for NIDs makes an explicit distinction between agents optimal strategies, and how they actually behave in reality.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text: In recent years, decision theory and game theory have had a profound impact on the conception of intelligent systems. Decision theory provides a mathematical language for decision-making in terms of uncertainty, whereas game theory extends this language to the multi-agent case. On a fundamental level, both approaches provide a definition of what it means to be an intelligent agent by equating intelligence with maximizing usage. Graphical languages such as the language I used (Pearl, 1988) have attracted a lot of attention because they allow a compact and natural representation of uncertainty in many areas that lead to representation, and these formalities often result in significant savings in representation and inference time.

sections.heading: 2.1 Multi-agent Influence Diagrams
sections.text: While Bayesian networks are used to indicate that agents are playing specific strategies, they do not capture the fact that agents are free to choose their own strategies, and they cannot be analyzed to calculate the optimal strategies for agents. Multi-agent influence diagrams (MAID) address these problems by extending Bayesian networks to strategic situations where agents must select the values of their decisions to maximize their own utilities, depending on the fact that other agents select the values of their decisions to maximize their own utilities. A MAID consists of a guided diagram with three types of nodes: Chance nodes, drawn as oval, represent decisions of nature, as in Bayesian networks. Decision nodes, drawn as rectangles, represent decisions of agents. Utility nodes, drawn as diamonds, represent the utility functions of agents. Each AID decision is associated with one MAID and one MAID decision.

sections.heading: 3. NID Semantics
sections.text: In this section we provide semantics for NIDs in the sense of MAIDs. We first show how an NID can be converted into a MAID. Then we define an NID equilibrium in the sense of a Nash equilibrium of the constructed MAID.

sections.heading: 3.2 Equilibrium Conditions
sections.text: In Section 2.1, we define pure and mixed strategies for decisions in MAIDs. In NIDs, we actually associate the decision strategies with the blocks in which they appear. A pure strategy for a decision D in a NID block K is a mapping from the informational parents of D to an action in the domain of D. Similarly, a mixed strategy for D is a mapping from the informational parents of D to a distribution across the domain of D. A strategy profile for an NID is a set of strategies for all decisions in the NID. Traditionally, a balance is defined for a game in terms of the best response strategies. A Nash balance is a strategy profile in which each agent can execute the best possible strategies for the strategies of the other agents. Classical game theory predicts that all agents will play a best answer. NIDs, on the other hand, allow us to describe situations in which an agent differs from his best response.

sections.heading: 4. Examples
sections.text: In this section, we present a number of examples demonstrating the usefulness of NIDs for describing and displaying uncertainty about decision-making processes in a variety of areas.

sections.heading: 4.1 Irrational Agents
sections.text: Since the challenge of perfect rationality is presented as the basis of Simon's (1955) economic systems, the theory of limited rationality has grown in different directions. From an economic point of view, limited rationality dictates a complete departure from the benefit-maximizing paradigm, in which concepts such as "optimization" and "objective functions" are actually replaced by "satisfaction" and "heuristics." (Gigerenzer & Rare, 2001) These concepts have recently been formalized by Rubinstein. From a traditional AI perspective, an agent will represent limited rationality if his program is a solution to the limited optimization problem caused by architecture or computational resources. NIDs serve the complementarity of these two dominant perspectives by allowing agents to behave irrationally in relation to their models.Irrationality.

sections.heading: 4.2 Conflicting Beliefs
sections.text: Traditional game theory assumes that agents "beliefs about each other's knowledge will be slow, resulting from the conditioning of a common approach to each agent's level of information; a consequence of this assumption is that agents" beliefs can differ only if they observe different information (Aumann & Brandenburger, 1995), resulting in a theoretical work that attempts to relax the common prior assumption. Myerson (1991) showed that a game with a contradictory belief structure that is finite can be transformed into a new game with consistent belief structures by constructing utility functions that correspond to the original game in a way that both assign the expected benefit to the agents. However, this new game will include beliefs and utility functions that are fundamentally different from the original game, which has contradictory belief structures. sections.heading: 4.3 Collusion and Alliances
sections.text: In a situation where one agent models multiple agents, it might be important to know if these agents cooperate in any way. In such situations, the models of how the other agents make their decisions can be correlated due to possible collusion. Example 4.4. A voting game involves 3 agents Alice, Bob and Bob Bob, who choose one of them to be chairman of a committee. Alice is the incumbent and will be chairman if the vote ends in a tie. Each agent wants to be chairman himself, and in this case receives a benefit of 2. Alice also gets a benefit of 1 if she votes for the winner but loses the election because she wants to look good. Bob and Carol, meanwhile, dislike Alice and get benefit of -1 if Alice's strategies of agents Bob and Carol are equal, and both vote for the same person. If Bob and Carol vote the same, it is indeed in Alice's best interest to vote for the person they are voting for.

sections.heading: 4.4 Cyclic Belief Structures
sections.text: Cyclic belief structures are important in game theory, where they are used to model agents that model themselves symmetrically. They are used to describe an infinite regression of "I think that you think that I think..." reasoning. Moreover, cyclic belief structures can be expressed in economic formalisms, such as Bob Bob Bob games, so it is crucial to allow them in NIDs so that NIDs include Bayean games. Cyclic belief structures can, of course, be captured in NIDs by including a cycle in the NID chart. Example 4.5. sections.heading: 5. Application: Opponent Modeling
sections.text: In some cases, agents use rules, heuristics, patterns or tendencies in decision-making. One of the most important approaches to playing with imperfect information is the modeling of the opponent, in which agents try to learn the patterns shown by other players and react to their model of others. NIDs provide a solid, coherent basis for modeling the opponent. Example 5.1. sections.heading: 5.2 Empirical Evaluation
sections.text: We evaluated the NID agent against the ten top candidates from the first automatic RoShamBo competition. All of these agents used an opponent's modeling approach, that is, they learned a signal of their opponent's game based on the history of previous rounds. Participants can be roughly classified into three dimensions: the type of signal used (probabilistic vs. deterministic); the type of reasoning used (pattern vs. meta-reasoners); and, their degree of exploration against the exploitation of their model. sections.heading: 6. Relationship with Economic Models
sections.text: In this section, we describe the relationship between NIDs and several existing formalities for displaying uncertainty about decision-making processes. NIDs share a close relationship with Bayesian games (Harsanyi, 1967), a game theory framework for displaying uncertainty about player payouts. Bayesian games capture the beliefs agents have about each other as well as define an equilibrium that are a best response strategy for each agent given his beliefs. Bayesian games are quite powerful in their ability to describe belief hierarchies and cyclical belief structures game structures. In a Bayesian game, each agent has a discrete type embodying its private information. sections.heading: 7. Conclusion
sections.text: A model in our language is a network of interconnected models in which each mental model is itself a graphical model of a game. An agent in a mental model may believe that another agent (or possibly himself) uses a different mental model to make decisions; there may be uncertainty about which mental model is used. We presented semantics for our language in the form of multi-agent influence charts. We analyzed the relationship between our language and Bayesian games. They are just as expressive, but NIDs can be exponentially more compact. We showed how our language can be used to describe agents who play irrationally, in the sense that their actual play does not correspond to the best possible response given their views of the world and other agents. This is captured by a novel concept of equilibrium that interacts between what agents should do and what they actually do. We also showed how situations where agents have conflicting beliefs.
